steps.title: The Ancient Problem
steps.narration: Long before computers existed, humans faced a simple challenge: How do we calculate things faster? From counting sheep to tracking stars, we needed tools to extend our minds.

steps.title: Stone: The Foundation
steps.narration: The first computers were made of stone‚Äîthe abacus! Today, we still use stone. Silicon, refined from sand and rock, forms the foundation of every computer chip in existence.

steps.title: Lightning: The Power
steps.narration: From Benjamin Franklin's kite to modern power grids, we learned to harness electricity. This same lightning-force now flows through every circuit, bringing machines to life.

steps.title: Magnetism: The Memory
steps.narration: Magnets have a superpower‚Äîthey remember which way they're pointing! North or south, on or off. This simple property became the foundation of all digital storage.

steps.title: The Transistor Revolution
steps.narration: In 1947, scientists combined silicon and electricity to create the transistor‚Äîa tiny switch smaller than a grain of sand. It turns on and off billions of times per second!

steps.title: Modern Computing
steps.narration: Today, your phone has 15 billion transistors, each smaller than a virus. The three ancient forces‚Äîstone, lightning, and magnetism‚Äîwork together in your pocket!

steps.title: The Humble Switch
steps.narration: A transistor is just a tiny switch. It can be ON or OFF. That's it! But here's the magic‚Äîwith enough switches working together, we can represent anything.

steps.title: Binary: Zeros and Ones
steps.narration: We call ON a 'one' and OFF a 'zero'. This two-symbol system is called binary. It's the only language computers truly understand.

steps.title: Position Matters
steps.narration: In binary, each position represents a power of two. From right to left: 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, and so on. The position of each 1 determines its value!

steps.title: Converting Binary
steps.narration: To convert binary to decimal, just add up the positions with 1s. For example, 1010 means 8 plus 0 plus 2 plus 0, which equals 10!

steps.title: Everything is Binary
steps.narration: Text, images, music, videos‚Äîeverything on your computer is stored as patterns of ones and zeros. This lesson you're reading right now? Just a very long binary number!

steps.title: The Library Analogy
steps.narration: Imagine a library with millions of books but no organization‚Äîjust books scattered everywhere. Finding anything would be impossible! Computers face the same challenge.

steps.title: Folders Organize Everything
steps.narration: The solution? Folders! Just like a filing cabinet, computers organize files into folders. Folders can contain other folders, creating a tree-like structure.

steps.title: Paths: File Addresses
steps.narration: Every file has an address called a path. Like slash Users slash YourName slash Projects slash hello.py. It tells the computer exactly where to find your file.

steps.title: The Terminal
steps.narration: Before pretty icons, there was only the terminal‚Äîa text-based interface where you type commands directly to the computer. Every developer uses it daily!

steps.title: Essential Commands
steps.narration: With just a few commands, you can navigate anywhere! 'pwd' shows where you are, 'ls' lists what's here, and 'cd' moves you to a new folder. You're in control!

questions.question: What are the three ancient forces that power modern computing?
questions.explanation: Stone (silicon) forms computer chips, lightning (electricity) powers them, and magnetism stores data. These three forces work together in every device!

questions.question: What is a transistor?
options: A tiny switch made of silicon that turns on and off
questions.explanation: A transistor is a microscopic switch made from silicon. Modern chips have billions of them, switching on and off billions of times per second!

questions.question: When was the transistor invented?
questions.explanation: The transistor was invented at Bell Labs in 1947, revolutionizing electronics and making modern computers possible.

questions.question: What does binary mean?
options: A system with only two symbols (0 and 1)
questions.explanation: Binary is a number system with only two symbols: 0 (off) and 1 (on). It's the fundamental language of all computers!

questions.question: What decimal number does binary 1100 represent?
What can be represented in binary?
options: Everything‚Äînumbers, text, images, videos, and more
questions.explanation: Binary can represent anything! All digital data‚Äîtext, images, music, videos‚Äîis ultimately stored as patterns of ones and zeros.

questions.question: What is a file path?
options: The address that tells a computer where to find a file
questions.explanation: A path is like a file's address. It shows the exact location from the root folder down to the file, like /Users/YourName/Documents/report.pdf

questions.question: What does the 'pwd' command do in the terminal?
options: Prints the current working directory (where you are)
questions.explanation: 'pwd' stands for 'print working directory'. It shows you exactly where you are in the file system‚Äîsuper helpful when navigating!

questions.question: What command lists the files and folders in your current location?
questions.explanation: 'ls' stands for 'list'. It shows you all the files and folders in your current directory. Add '-la' to see hidden files too!
